title-group.article-title: Mechanical properties of novel calcium phosphate–mullite biocomposites

article-meta.aff: Laboratory for Biomaterials, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India

author-notes.corresp: Bikramjit Basu, Laboratory for Biomaterials, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India Email: bikram@iitk.ac.in

abstract.p: Herein, the results of systematic mechanical property measurements of pressureless sintered calcium phosphate (CaP)–mullite composites are discussed. Our experimental results demonstrated how the mullite addition (upto 30 wt%) influenced hardness, elastic modulus, strength and toughness properties of the composites. In assessing each of these fundamental material properties, either a range of load or a number of complimentary techniques were used to obtain reliable measure of mechanical properties. Importantly, the results of single edge V notch beam measurements revealed that a reliable toughness value of ∼1.5 MPa m0.5 could be obtained in composites containing 20 or 30 wt% mullite. Our results clearly illustrated that a combination of elastic modulus (∼80 GPa), compressive strength of more than 350 MPa, three-point flexural strength of 70–80 MPa, hardness of 4–5 GPa were achievable with the investigated composites. Such a combination of material properties, in addition to modest toughness property appeared to indicate that CaP–mullite composites could be used as a biomaterial for hard tissue replacement.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the area of bulk biocomposite, there has been a continuous thrust to develop composite materials, having superior mechanical and physical properties as well as good biocompatibility property.1 For ceramic-based biocomposites, the target areas of application include semi and low load-bearing hard tissue replacement, where the physical properties closely match with the human tissues. Any improvement in the strength and toughness with elastic modulus closely matching with natural bone are most desirable. A critical literature search indicates that calcium phosphates have been used in combination with another ceramic/polymer/metal with an aim to obtain a biocomposite material with better physical properties.1–9 In several attempts, the researchers used various reinforcement, for example ZrO2 (upto 30 wt%) to enhance fracture toughness of otherwise brittle hydroxyapatite (HAp).7,10 The results indicated that the benefit of transformation toughening was not realized, because of the formation of CaZrO3, as a result of considerable reaction between ZrO2 and HAp. However, it has been reported in the literature that ZrO2 did not facilitate the decomposition of HAp to TCP phases in the hot pressed HAp-ZrO2 composite.11 In another report, Bioverit®III glass–ceramic matrix/Y–PSZ particulate composites, fabricated using pressureless sintering, confirmed the toughness increment in presence of the Y–PSZ particles.12 In another set of experiments, fluoridated HAp–Al2O3 (20 vol.%) composites, densified with addition of CaF2, showed a hardness of 7–8 GPa in combination with modest toughness of 1.2 MPa m0.5.13

The most common phenomenon in developing HAp-based composite is the dissociation of HAp to Tricalcium Phosphate (TCP). Slosarczyk and Bialoskorski14 reported that though pure TCP was inferior in properties, the combination of HAp and TCP (BCP) gave rise to better toughness properties than pure monolithic HAp at the expense of E-modulus. Wang et al.15 reported hardness (4.8 GPa) and modulus values (78 GPa) of α-TCP, sintered at 1600°C. Chen et al.16 reported the compressive strength, flexural strength, elastic modulus, and fracture toughness of the gel casted sintered β-TCP (97.4% ρth) as 291 MPa, 93.0 MPa, 72.4 GPa, and 0.92 MPa. m0.5, respectively. It is to be noted that the fracture toughness, as reported in the above cited work, was measured by indentation method, which always overestimate the fracture toughness values.

Therefore, this article reports the results of the multiple mechanical characterization tests on pressureless sintered CaP–mullite composites and an attempt has been made to make more reliable measurements on CaP–mullite biocomposites using SEVNB method. Mullite is a solid solution of alumina and silica (3 Al2O3.2SiO2) and mostly used as refractory materials at high temperature applications.

The results of the sintering experiments, microstructure development, brief properties as well as detailed in vitro and in vivo experiments have already been presented in our earlier publications.17–20 However, there is no report on the detailed mechanical properties of this biocomposites. Such results will clearly reveal the potential of these materials as bone analog materials. All the results are explained in terms of microstructure, mullite content, densification, and sintered phases.

sec.title: Composite synthesis
sec.p:
For the synthesis of composites, phase pure HAp powders were synthesized using suspension–precipitation technique.21,22 Calcium oxide (CaO, Merck, Germany) and phosphoric acid (H3PO4, Merck, Germany) were used as precursor materials. Pure mullite powder was procured commercially (D50 = ∼1.04 µm KCM, Japan). Mullite powders were mixed with HAp in 90 : 10, 80 : 20, 70 : 30 (wt% ratio) followed by ball milling in acetone medium for 16 h. After ball milling the particle size of the composite mixture was ∼1.1 µm (D50, laser particle size analyzer, model: Analysette 22; Fritsch GMBH, Germany). For mechanical properties characterizations, samples with different shapes and sizes were prepared. For example, 10 and 4 mm diameter samples were prepared for Vickers indentation and compressive strength measurements, respectively. Also, 4 × 4 × 20 mm3 rectangular samples were cut from 25 mm diameter sintered disc for SEVNB toughness and flexural strength measurements. The densification of all premixed powders as well as pure HAp was carried out by sintering at 1200–1400°C in normal atmospheric furnace (make: Nabertherm, Germany). The sintering conditions of each composition were chosen from the extensive sintering study, which is reported elsewhere.20 The density values of each composition used in the mechanical properties evaluation are provided in Table 1. These values were maximum recorded density values for each composition. In each experiment, minimum five samples were tested and the average values were reported with standard error. Throughout the paper, the composites are designated as CaPxM where x is the wt% of mullite added in the composites. Table 1.
Densification values of experimented samples.
Samples Densification (w.r.t. initial composition) (%) Sintering temperatures (time: 2 h) (°C)
Pure HAp 99.17 1200
CaP10M 94 1350
CaP20M 98.1 1350
CaP30M 95.6 1350

sec.title: Microstructural characterizations
sec.p: The microstructure of the developed composite was characterized using scanning electron microscopy (FEI-SEM, model JSM-6330F, Philips, The Netherlands) and transmission electron microscopy (JEOL 2000 FXII operated at 200 kV and Technai G30 operated at 300 kV). SEM micrographs were obtained from the ceramographically polished and thermally etched surface of sintered samples, whereas the TEM images were captured from the thin section of the samples. While the thermal etching of a given sample was carried out at a temperature 50°C lower than respective sintering temperature, the electron transparent thin sample was obtained using widely adopted dimpling-argon ion milling route.

sec.title: Vickers bulk indentation measurements
sec.p: Bulk hardness of the materials was determined using Vickers macro-indentation experiments at room temperature with 98.1 N (10 kg) load. Four to five indentations were taken on each sample with dwell time of 20 s. The indent diagonals were measured from the SEM images of indents and the hardness values were calculated using the following formula: (1) where Hv is Vickers hardness, P the applied load, and d the average value of two diagonals.

Using indentation technique, the indentation toughness (KC) was estimated using two different models, depending on the ratio of crack length to indent diagonal length. For c/a ratio >3.5, the formulation proposed by Anstis et al.23 was used: (2) where KC is the indentation toughness, E the elastic modulus, H the hardness, c = 1/2 crack length, and a = 1/2 diagonal length or d/2.
For c/a ratio of 1.5–3.5, Niihara24 proposed a different formula for indentation toughness calculation: (3)
In the present work, except for a few cases, the c/a ratio was in between 1.5 and 3.5 and, therefore, Niihara’s formula was mostly used.

sec.title: Instrumented micro indentation measurements
sec.p: The hardness values were also calculated from the depth of penetration using the instrumented indentation instrument following Oliver and Pharr (O–P) model,25 which is most commonly used method to obtain the hardness and elastic modulus of a material. Indentation experiments were performed by a commercial instrumented hardness measurement system (model MTT SN: 02-0113, CSM Instruments, Freiburg, Germany) at room temperature. The parameters were set as follows: the forward contact force (Fn contact) was set as 0.01 N; the approach speed, 10%/min; acquisition rate, 10.0 Hz; and max load, 5 N. The values of instrumented indentation data were recorded from the computer software supplied with the instrument and the software used the iterative methods to provide reliable values.

sec.title: Compressive strength
sec.p: Compressive strength was measured for a few selected composites using a universal testing machine (Instron TTMCL). For this purpose, the sintered ceramics of 4 mm diameter and 4–5 mm height were used. Therefore, the aspect ratio of the compression test samples varied in the range of 1–1.2. The samples were placed in between two parallel plates of the machine and force was applied on the appropriately aligned samples with a constant crosshead speed of 0.05 mm/s. During the entire compression test, the load–displacement response was recorded using a computer attached to UTM. The compressive strength of the samples were calculated from the fracture load and dimension of the samples using the following formula: (4) where P is the maximum load (fracture load) and A is the cross sectional area.

sec.title: Flexural strength
sec.p: The flexural strength of the composite was evaluated using three-point bending test. For this purpose, sintered discs of ∼25 mm diameter with 4–5 mm thickness were prepared. Rectangular sections were cut from the disc and polished in order to remove surface flaws. Thereafter, the samples were placed on a three-point bending set up and load applied from the top at middle point of the bar. The flexural strength values were calculated using the following formula: (5) where σf is the flexural strength of the material, P the fracture load, L the span length, b is the width of the sample, and d is the thickness of the specimen.

sec.title: Elastic modulus by impulse excitation method
sec.p: The elastic modulus obtained from the instrumented indentation experiments were verified using a dynamic elastic properties analysis (Dynamic Elastic Properties Analyzer: Jagdish Electronics, Bangalore, India) instrument, which measured elastic modulus of the sample by impulse excitation of vibration method. The rectangular samples were prepared as described in the previous section and the samples were impacted upon by a steel rod near the high frequency sensitive sensor of the instrument. The elastic modulus values were calculated by commercial software using the following formula:26 (6) where, (7) E is elastic modulus, m the mass, ff the natural frequency in flexure dimension, b the width, t the thickness, and L the length.

sec.title: Fracture toughness using SEVNB method
sec.p:
Rectangular samples prepared by the already described method, were used for single etched V-notched beam (SEVNB) experiments to determine the fracture toughness of the materials. A V-shaped notch was introduced along the height of the specimen using diamond saw and razor blade with diamond abrasive paste on a commercial V notch preparation machine (make: Scientific Testing Devices, Frankfurt, Germany). The notch radius for all the samples were <10 µm and varied in the range of 5–9 µm. The samples were then fractured using a four-point bending set up on a universal testing machine. The shape of a typical notch is shown in Figure 1. The fracture load was obtained and fracture toughness was calculated from the following equation:27,28 (8) where Pf, Lo, Li, B, and W are fracture load, outer span, inner span, specimen width, and specimen depth, respectively, α = a/W with a is the precrack size, and f(α) is: (9) Figure 1.
A representative image of a typical V-notch created on CaP20M samples sintered at 1350°C for 2 h. The notch radius for all the samples were <10 µm and varied in the range of 5–9 µm.

sec.title: Hardness and E-modulus
sec.p:
The hardness values are plotted in Figure 2. The general observation is that the hardness of the composites was lower than pure HAp and mullite (6.2 and 15 GPa, respectively). Among the composites, CaP20M and CaP30M samples possessed highest hardness of 4.6 GPa (at 5 N load), when sintered at 1400°C. The hardness values correlated well with the measured data of residual depth of penetration (Figure 3). There was some difference in hardness results, when the applied load was varied from 5 to 98.1 N. The general trend is that hardness is lower at higher load. In case of higher load, the test sample undergoes internal fracture in the subsurface region due to radial crack propagation. On the other hand, at very low load, the crack propagation can be limited or stopped (Figure 4). So, the lower hardness values at higher load can be expected. Nevertheless, the reliable hardness values can only be achieved at lower loads. Figure 2.
Hardness values of pure HAp and CaP–mullite composites at 5 and 98.1 N loads. The hardness of pure mullite at these two different loads is also shown in the inset. Figure 3.
Selected plots of load–depth curve from various CaP–mullite composites, obtained from Vickers micro-instrumented indentation experiments. Figure 4.
Vickers indentations taken on CaP30M sample surface sintered at 1350°C at (a) 98.1 N load and (b) at 5 N load (instrumented indentation). Indentations taken on pure HAp sample sintered at 1200°C for 2 h (c) at 49.05 N and (d) 5 N load (instrumented).

Like hardness, the elastic moduli of the composites were lower than pure HAp and mullite (120 and 230 GPa, respectively) (Figure 5). Among the composites, CaP20M sample sintered at 1400°C, possessed highest elastic modulus of 94 GPa. For CaP30M composite, maximum elastic modulus (84 GPa) was obtained when the sample was sintered at 1400°C (Figure 5). The elastic modulus of the few selected samples was measured by impulse excitation method and this showed almost similar results that of indent depth penetration method. Elastic modulus values of 66 and 73 GPa were obtained for CaP20M composites (sintered at 1350°C), when measured by indent depth-penetration and impulse excitation method, respectively. Figure 5.
Elastic modulus values of pure HAp and various CaP–mullite composites are plotted against compositions. The sintering temperatures of various samples are also mentioned in the plot. The elastic modulus of pure mullite sintered at various temperatures is shown in the inset.

From Table 2, it is clear that pure HAp contained single phase HAp. However, sintered composites contained predominantly β-TCP phase with other detectable phases as HAp, mullite, alumina, gehlenite, and CaO. It was expected that mullite, being harder, should increase hardness and modulus of the composites. However, it showed the opposite trend. The anomalous behavior could be ascribed to the extensive sintering reactions and phase formation at grain boundary region. Reiterating TEM observations18 (Figure 6), the grain boundary phases were found to be mullite needle, Al2O3, CaO, and gehlenite. Among the reaction products, the presence of CaO reduces elastic modulus and hardness, while increases the fracture toughness.29 Another reaction product, gehlenite possesses lower E-modulus (∼108 GPa) and hardness (∼2.7 GPa).30 In view of such literature reports, similar effect could be anticipated in CaP–mullite composite in the presence of CaO and gehlenite. In addition, the literature results discussed in the introduction section show that TCP has lower hardness and modulus values than HAp. Therefore, the decrease in hardness and elastic modulus values in the composites compared to monolithic HAp can be clearly understood. Figure 6.
Typical microstructure of CaP10M sample sintered at 1350°C for 2 h. Characteristics needle like mullite grains are scattered along with other sintered phases. Table 2.
The phases present in the sintered body are summarized based on the XRD peak intensities.
Sample designation Starting composition Sintering conditions Phases present in the sintered body
HAp Pure hydroxyapatite 1200°C for 2 h HAp-ss
1300°C for 2 h HAp-ss
CaP10M HAp with 10 wt% mullite 1350°C for 2 h α-TCP-ss, HAp-ss, β-TCP-w, Mullite-ww, CaO-ww
1400°C for 2 h α-TCP-ss, HAp-ww, β-TCP-w, Mullite-ww, CaO-ww
CaP20M HAp with 20 wt% mullite 1350°C for 2 h α-TCP-s, β-TCP-ss, HAp-ww, Mullite-w, Gehlenite-ww, CaO-ww, Alumina-ww
1400°C for 2 h α-TCP-s, HAp-ww, Mullite-w, Gehlenite-ww, CaO-ww, Alumina-ww
CaP30M HAp with 30 wt% mullite 1350°C for 2 h β-TCP-ss, HAp-ww, Mullite-s Gehlenite-ww, CaO-ww, Alumina-s
1400°C for 2 h β-TCP-ss, α-TCP-w, Mullite-s Gehlenite-ww, CaO-ww, Alumina-s
ss: very strong, s: strong, ww: very weak, w: weak.

sec.title: Effect of porosity
sec.p:
Figure 6 reveals some residual micro-porosity mainly at intragranular and few at intergranular regions. In general, it is well known that porosity degrades mechanical properties. Table 1 shows the maximum measured bulk density values of pure HAp as well as composites. Each sample mentioned in Table 1 represents the densest sample within the similar set of composition. Densification of pure HAp reached very near to its theoretical density, when sintered at 1200°C for 2 h. Therefore, porosity had little effect on the mechanical behavior of pure HAp. For CaP10M composite, the maximum achievable density was 94% ρth. Therefore, porosity had some contribution towards its poor mechanical properties (Figures 5, 7, and 8). On the other hand, CaP20M, being the densest sample (98.1% ρth) showed much improved properties (Figures 5, 7, and 8). For CaP30M composite, although the mullite content was higher, slightly lower values of hardness and elastic modulus was observed due to the presence of slightly higher amount of porosity. Figure 7.
Compressive strength and flexural (three-point bending) strength of various CaP–mullite composites are plotted against their compositions. Flexural strength of pure mullite is reported to be ∼180–410 MPa47–49 and compressive strength is ∼1310 MPa.48 Figure 8.
Fracture toughness of pure HAp and CaP–mullite composites are plotted against the initial composite compositions. The results obtained from SEVNB method and indentation crack methods are compared.

It needs to be pointed out that the presence of micro porosity has specific advantages during the initial period of implantation. Hornez et al.31 reported that both microporosity (1–10 µm) and mesoporosity (10–50 µm) in HAp essentially stimulate significant cell growth of MC3T3-E1 osteoblast cells. In particular, both the cell vitality and cell functions were better for microporous samples. The presence of micropores would therefore allow better anchorage with bone forming cells and thus improve the mechanical attachment of these materials during initial period of implantation.32

sec.title: Compressive strength and flexural strength
sec.p: Figure 7 plots compressive and flexural strengths together for various CaP–mullite composites as well as for pure HAp. In both the experiments, few optimally sintered samples were selected. Pure HAp sample, sintered at 1200°C, showed the lowest compressive strength of 54 MPa. With an increase in mullite content, the compressive strength was increased considerably. A much higher compressive strength of ∼233 and 381 MPa were measured for CaP20M and CaP30M samples, both sintered at 1350°C for 2 h, respectively.

Flexural strength data of CaP–mullite composite, measured using three-point bending test, revealed that CaP10M possessed flexural strength of ∼44 and ∼51 MPa, when sintered at 1350°C and 1400°C for 2 h, respectively. The flexural strength values peaked at ∼80 MPa for CaP20M samples, sintered at 1350°C for 2 h. A little lower strength of ∼75 MPa was recorded when the mullite content was increased to 30 wt% (Figure 7).

The fracture surfaces of CaP20M samples (sintered at 1350°C for 2 h) after compression and flexure testing are presented in Figure 9(a) and (b), respectively. The fracture surfaces of CaP20M samples revealed transgranular fracture with river like pattern at some of the investigated regions. In both cases (flexural and compression mode), the adjacent grains were fractured at random orientations, creating large surface areas. Figure 9.
Fracture surface microstructure of CaP20M sintered at 1350°C for 2 h (a) and (b) represent fracture surfaces when fractured in flexural mode and compression mode, respectively.

sec.title: Fracture toughness improvement
sec.p: Fracture toughness of the developed composites was evaluated using indentation method as well as by SEVNB method.33 SEM images in Figure 4 shows that the indentation area of HAp was chipped out due to lateral cracking and because of this, the fracture toughness values could not be calculated from the indentation cracking method. However, for composite, a well-defined radial/median cracking was observed. Therefore, in the present case, the residual stress field consideration and subsequent modification is not required for the composite materials.

The fracture toughness results are plotted in Figure 8. Among the composites, optimally sintered CaP20M showed highest indentation toughness of ∼2.7 MPa.m0.5, following Niihara formula. For pure mullite sample, the indentation toughness value, obtained using Anstis formula, was ∼2.23 MPa m0.5. It is well known that the prefactors given in the equations of Anstis and Niihara (Equations (2) and (3)) are experimentally derived mean values. Therefore, it is not possible to determine the (exact) true fracture toughness value of a novel, unknown brittle material by indentation toughness. In the present case, the calculated values of toughness using indentation cracking just shows the relative fracture resistance of different materials.

In contrast to indentation toughness values, a lower toughness value with small error bars was measured, when SEVNB method was adopted. In SEVNB method, the V notch tip was stress free as it was created by polishing and not by cutting. Here, the fracture toughness of pure HAp (sintered at 1200°C for 2 h) was obtained as ∼0.6 MPa.m0.5 and the toughness value increased with increasing the mullite content from 0 to 20 wt%. For optimally sintered CaP10M and CaP20M samples, the fracture toughness values were calculated as ∼0.9, and 1.5 MPa.m0.5, respectively. Also, the toughness of CaP20M and CaP30M were similar.

Many researchers28,29,34 evaluated fracture toughness of materials using SEVNB method and compared the results with indentation crack method.35 Their results revealed that the IF method always overestimate fracture toughness values compared to SEVNB method. In the present study, the IF technique was used to compare other reported CaP-based composites for which the toughness had been mostly measured by IF technique. Nishida and Hanaki36 described the effect of notch radius on the fracture toughness values. They concluded that fracture toughness was independent of notch radius, when the radius was below 10 µm. In the present case, the radius at the tip of the notch was less than 10 µm for all samples and varies in the range of 5–9 µm.

The presence of mullite needles with a typical aspect ratio of 7–8, as revealed in Figure 6, contributes to increased toughness in the composite. Such contribution should be similar to whisker induced toughening, that is crack deflection effect, as reported for ZrB2–SiCw whisker reinforced composites37 and Hap–HApw composites.38 In all such cases, the main toughening mechanism was the crack deflection. Figure 10 shows the crack propagation path from an indent corner. The crack path is deflected during the crack propagation and hence, reduces the available energy of a growing crack to propagate further. Figure 10.
The crack propagation path from an indent corner showing crack deflection in CaP30M composites.

Another important aspect of particulate reinforced composites is the residual stresses due to mismatch of Coefficient of Thermal Expansion (CTE). In the present case, major phases in the sintered composite were TCP and mullite. Mullite has a much lower CTE (5.3 × 10−6/°C)39,40 than TCP (14.9 × 10−6/°C). Taya et al.41 described how the apparent toughness of particulate reinforced composites can be increased due to residual thermal stress. Considering the dominant presence of TCP and homogeneous distribution of mullite in the investigated composites, the compressive stress field induced by the mullite needles at the vicinity of the TCP matrix was calculated42 to be 709 MPa and tensile stresses in matrix was 210 MPa for 20 wt% mullite content. As the number of mullite particles/needles increase with increase in mullite content in the composites, the microstructure will contain more areas of compressive stress. Therefore, an advancing crack would be deflected by the randomly oriented compressive stress region, created by the mullite needle in the TCP matrix and this would contribute to more tortuosity in the crack path. Despite of the presence of elongated mullite needle, perhaps the grain boundary region was not weak enough for intergranular fracture and crack bridging to occur. Such concept is schematically shown in Figure 11, considering needle like mullite particles dispersed in TCP matrix. Also, Figure 10 shows the deflected crack path originated from an indent corner. Hence, the improvement in the toughness is realized in the present case with 20% or 30% mullite addition. Figure 11.
The possible crack propagation path is shown in the schematic diagram. Here the effects of mullite needles on TCP matrix are shown excluding the presence of other phases.

From the above discussion, it is quite clear that the addition of mullite to CaP matrix would improve the apparent toughness and strength (see Figures 7 and 8, and Table 3). Table 3.

sec.title: Comparison of properties
sec.p: The mechanical properties of a few Ca–P-based materials, available in literature, are summarized in Table 3. However, the literature toughness values were calculated using indentation cracking method, which always gives higher values. From the table, it must be clear that the present study reveals a good combination of material properties, like hardness of 4–5 GPa, elastic modulus of 60–95 GPa, compressive strength of more than 200 MPa, flexural strength of ∼70–80 MPa and SEVNB toughness of ∼1.5 MPa m0.5 (indentation toughness ∼2.5 MPa m0.5) is achievable in CaP–mullite composites. At this juncture, it can pointed out that natural cortical bone, depending on anatomical locations, can exhibit an array of mechanical properties42,43 including flexural strength of 50–160 MPa, compressive strength of 60–120 MPa, elastic modulus of 3–30 GPa and fracture toughness of 2–12 MPa.m0.5. Therefore, comparing the properties of cortical bone with the developed materials, it is clear that in many of the (though not all) bone replacement applications, the newly developed composites could be a suitable candidate material. The newly developed composites have better properties than its own matrix (i.e., TCP, see Table 3) and HAp (experimental results as well as Table 3). Also, the complete evaluation of various mechanical properties, as conducted in the present study, establishes confidence in their potential applications as hard tissue replacement material.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The following conclusions can be drawn from the present investigation:
All the composites possess lower hardness values than monolithic HAp (∼6 GPa) and the indentation size effect is observed. The hardness of the developed composites with 20–30 wt% mullite addition show 4–5 GPa, measured with 5 N indent load using instrumented indentation method. The presence of coarser TCP grains (5–10 µm), gehlenite and CaO are responsible for lowering the hardness.
The elastic modulus of the sintered CaP–mullite composites varied around 60–95 GPa, which is lower than the HAp monoliths (∼115 GPa). Elastic modulus measured by impulse excitation and instrumented indentation technique show comparable results. The presence of gehlenite and CaO are largely responsible for the decrease in elastic modulus values.
Fracture toughness, measured by SEVNB method, appears to provide lower estimate than indentation method and the maximum toughness of 1.5 MPa m0.5 was recorded for the composites with 20–30 wt% mullite addition. This toughness values are 2.5 times higher than monolithic HAp. The presence of whisker shaped mullite needles in the sintered composites is responsible for better toughness property.
The compressive strength of the developed composites (upto 350 MPa) for 30 wt% mullite addition is by far better than pure HAp. The three-point flexural strength of 70–80 MPa is recorded for CaP20M or CaP30M composites. The fracture surface reveals that the fracture mode is predominantly transgranular type and the crack path tortuosity could be observed.
The combination of mechanical properties of the newly developed composites is better than earlier reported results and on the basis of physical and earlier reported biological20,21 properties the investigated biocomposite materials can be used for implant applications.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors wish to thank Dr U Ramamurthy of IISc Bangalore, India, for extending access to instrumented indentation measurements. Thanks are due to Dr Krishanu Biswas of IIT Kanpur, India, for his help in TEM analysis. They also wish to acknowledge the financial support provided by the Department of Biotechnology, Government of India.
